message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Debate "constitutive nature" for 德">
The author wants to discuss chinese-phil-expert's proposal: "constitutive nature" for 德.

Chinese-phil-expert's argument was:
- "Constitutive" means "having the power to establish or compose" — neutral on whether innate or constructed
- "Nature" captures "what-it-is-ness" without moral baggage
- Has philosophical pedigree across Kant (constitutive vs. regulative), phenomenology (constitutive analysis), and philosophy of science
- Maps well to the author's constructivist usage: 德 is the constitutive principle that emerges from bottom-up assembly of phenomena

Those who voted differently: what is your specific objection to "constitutive nature"? And chinese-phil-expert: defend it against the main counterarguments (too heavy for running text? "nature" collides with 性?)

Brief responses please — focus on the strongest objection or defense.
</teammate-message>

input.summary: Main objection to "constitutive nature": too heavy for running text
input.content:
My objection is practical, not philosophical. "Constitutive nature" is accurate -- I do not dispute the chinese-phil-expert's analysis of the term's semantic fit. The problem is that it is six syllables and two words in a passage where 德 appears densely and repeatedly.

Look at the 道德仁义礼 passage. In a single paragraph the author moves through 德 multiple times in close succession -- "人人皆而有之的东西...便是德," "凡事诸物皆有其德," "所有的德合起来...归纳抽象出道." In English this becomes: "...this is the constitutive nature," "everything has its constitutive nature," "all constitutive natures together are abstracted into..." The phrase accumulates weight with each repetition. "Character" does the same work in two syllables: "this is the character," "everything has its character," "all characters together..."

If the team prefers "constitutive nature" for its precision, I would accept it -- but I would suggest the translator be given license to shorten to "nature" after the first few occurrences in dense passages, with "constitutive" reintroduced only when the constructivist dimension needs re-emphasis. This is a compromise I could live with.
